title: ITO-MASTER: Inference-Time Optimization for Audio Effects Modeling of Music Mastering Processors
author: Junghyun Koo (Sony AI, Japan), Marco A. Martínez-Ramírez (Sony AI, Japan), Wei-Hsiang Liao (Sony AI, Japan), Giorgio Fabbro (Sony Europe B.V., Germany), Michele Mancusi (Sony Europe B.V., Germany), Yuki Mitsufuji (Sony AI, Japan), ...
relevance_why: The proposed ITO-Master framework enhances mastering style transfer through inference-time optimization, which could be valuable for guidance in audio and music processing tasks, aligning with my interests in audio quality enhancement.
background: Automated music mastering involves adapting the mastering characteristics of a reference track to enhance a target track, simulating a professional mastering process.
contribution: This paper introduces the ITO-Master framework to solve user control limitations in audio effects modeling during mastering, achieving improved adaptability and performance in audio mastering tasks.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods lacked user control and flexibility, applying fixed processing without options for fine-tuning.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work allows dynamic refinement of audio effects by optimizing the reference embedding during inference, significantly enhancing user adaptability.

key_innovation: The ability to optimize reference embeddings in real-time for audio mastering, enabling more precise control over mastering effects.
real_world_impact: The framework provides a practical solution for both professionals and amateurs in the music industry, enhancing the flexibility and quality of automated music mastering processes.

new_terms.Inference-Time Optimization: **Inference-Time Optimization** refers to the process of adjusting model parameters or embeddings during the inference phase rather than during training, to enhance performance dynamically.
new_terms.maximizing cosine similarity: **Maximizing cosine similarity** is a metric-based optimization approach that seeks to align the direction of two vectors, thus ensuring they are as similar as possible in terms of their orientation in space.

open_sourcing: The implementation details can be found in an open-source repository.
